{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3213358,"name":"Joshua Epperson","username":"jepperson","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/74df32/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-06-09T15:04:49.150Z","cooked":"

I want to make a way to make a single big artery wire connector for our swerve modules and I was wondering how to do it with the stuff we already have. I know andersons can easily do this but our team already has insulated wire connectors. How would I design an internal locking mechanism for them so thst way I can stack them and make the connector?

If I am understanding the connector here, (Something like this): it may be worth 3d printing some 2x_ clips with internal geometry that rides against the back of the bullet, that prevents it from pulling out as much. Then just put holes in place where a zip tie or other locking thing can go in.
Something like this:

Screenshot 2023-06-09 11.37.47 AM505×513 55.2 KB

Assuming you’re looking at these types?

image1441×654 105 KB

Whelp, to break the problem down - a locking mechanism implies you have something to provide a locking force between multiple connectors.

There’s little to no mechanical surface to brace against on those connectors, so it’s going to be tough to design something. Glue or adhesives might be an option, abet inelegant.

Press-fit (friction) might be an option, but since the connectors themselves rely on press-fit, the locking mechanism has to be stronger than the connector itself (otherwise the whole thing will just disassemble when you disconnect the rig).

TL;DR maybe, but those connectors aren’t designed to be joined into a single bundle.

Something to consider when making multiple connectors into a larger block is the mating/unmasking forces required for the block.

On a previous team, the student doing the electrical work insisted on locking as many of the Anderson connectors together as he could. While it looked nice, it was very difficult to service because it tooka lot of force to pry the two sides apart. We ended up breaking the block up into pairs.
